div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: WHITE AND COLOURED LABOUR
div.p: The seriousness of the economic problem which arises when Eastern and Western labour come into conflict was discussed in "Public Opinion" last week, especially' in relation to Japan and the United States. But the same problem is to the front in Australia and in South Africa. Take Australia-it has adopted A deliberate policy of exclusion for the Japanese. Mr. C-R W. Bean, of Sydney, writing to the " Spectator," says "A Western and Oriental race cannot live together in Australia. The resolve of Australians to keep their country white is of an intensity undreamed of in England." May there not he something, he asks, in the fact that "while the Briton who never meets the Oriental declares that East and West can live side by side, his own race wherever in the world it meets an Oriental people refuses to live si"P by side with it 1 The Englishman in India is the strongest case in point. "No one," he adds, "can deny the danger of an Oriental overflow. There are some three million odd whites in Australia inhabiting three million square miles. To the North,at its very gates, up to within a day's sail are eight hundred million Orientals.' The weakest point that I can see in the Australian case h in the moral problem. Have we, so few, a right to keep out these hordes and save Australia for ourselves f But then-Is it for ourselves or for the forty million white men to come after, and for the perpetuation of our race and the ideals we believe in, and, above all, for our children ? Are they to look to ns for a healthy home-or for that mixed horror f Senator Pulsford, commenting on this letter says that "no one would dream from reading it that Japan had actually made repeated offers to Australia to enter int4> some treaty or arrangement controlling the emigration of Japanese to Australia so as to secure to Australia everything she desired, and that Australia, instead of availing herself of the courteous offers made by Japan, preferred to deal With the whole subject of the restriction of immigration in a way which was clearly shown to be offen sive to the public spirit of the people of Japau." There are many in Australia, adds fh'e Senator, "who do view with doep regret tho fact that certain Australian legislation tonds to create Empire difficulties that more courteous methods would obviate." In the Transvaal the problem is compli cated by the fact that the antipathy to ooloured men in this oase means antipathy to members of the same Empire, for the coloured men who have invaded Natal ami the Transvaal, and whose coming has been resisted, are Indiana Lord Selborne says there can be no mistaking the strength of the unanimous demand oi all sections of tho white community iq the Transvaal for the passing of an Acl making Registration for Asiatics compulsory The oflensive part, however, of the Registration Act is that which provides for the identification of holders of certificates by means of fingerprint impressions. General Botha, it is said, will try and adopt some less dffensive means of registration. But at bottom the objection to the Asiatic in the Transvaal and Natal is economic. They take away business from the whites, and that is a ground of oftence.

div.p: During the absence in Europe of Mr. ROWLAND SNELLING, Editor and Manager of the "Egyptian Gazette," all cheques and receipts will be signed by Mr. G. I SWANSON, acting Editor and Manager, and countersigned by Mr. A. MARAVELLI, Cashier. 80788-152

div.head: S.P.C.A
div.p: The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to animals has engaged four new inspectors, of which two are for Cairo and two for the suburbs.

div.head: Lamp Explosion.
div.p: At Bab el Charieh, a young native girl, named Nabilia, Aly, living in the rue Bein-el-Sayarev, was badly burnt by the explosion of a spirit lamp containing alcohol, over which she was boiling water. The doctor declares it an extremely grave case.

div.head: Bathing Fatality.
div.p: On Saturday morning, at Helouan, a small native boy, named Ismail, was bathing in a large basin attached to a steam mill, when he was attacked by cramp. The boy sank and was drowned in a few moments. His body was recovered by a mechanic.

div.head: Return Railway Tickets.
div.p: The Administration of the State Railways have decided to reinstitute return tickets They will bè issued from the 1st of January 1908 the rebate being we understand 15% of the double fare. The issue will only be made to and from the larger stations.

div.head: A Foundling.
div.p: Ou Sunday evening a new-born male child wan found in the Waily quarter near the Khédivial Observatory at Cairo, abandoned by its parents. The child was immediately taken by the police to the hospital where it was received in the special ward for infants. The police are seaching for some clue to the parents.

div.head: Custom House Regulations.
div.p: A petition is circulating at Port Said, addressed to the Custom House Administration protesting against the modifications concerning the rules for the exportation of merchandise. These modifications impose an additional charge for the dispatching of goods, causing a day's delay, and it is alleged, serious deterioration by the opening of parcels.

div.head: Biography of Cecil Rhodes
div.p: It is announced that the Rhodes Trustees have selected one of their number, Sir Lewis Michell, to collect materials for a life of the late Mr. Cecil Rhodes. The trustees will be greatly obliged if any persons having letters from, or other papers of interest relating to Mr. Rhodes will send them to Sir lewis Michell, St Albans, who will acknowledge receipt and be responsible for their safe return.

div.head: Patriaroh of Antioch
div.p: At the last meeting of the Council of the Orthodox Patriarchate of Alexandria, notice was given of a letter received from Mgr. Gregoire, recently elected patriarch of Antioch, demanding the ratification of his election. The Patriarchate has refused to acceed to this request and has declared itself in opposition to his appointment to the episcopal throne, alleging that Mgr. Gregoire is of Arab nationality.

div.head: Cotton Growing in the West Indies
div.p: Sir Alfred Jones has received the following letter from Sir Daniel Morris, the Imperial Commissioner for Agriculture in the West Indies:-" You will rejoice to hoar that the prospects of cotton for next year are favourable. We have had nice rains, and the cotton growers are planting first-class seeds supplied them by this Department." A system has been started in Jamaica, under the auspices of Sir Alfred Jones to encourage cotton growing by the peasants. An experiment made last year was very successful, and it, is hoped that this year, when many acres will be planted, the same success will be achieved. An advance is made to the extent of £10 per acre, the crop being taken as security. This system is to some extent modelled upon Lord Cromer's policy in this country which was a conspicuous success.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S GRANT
HALF HEARTED OPPOSITION
div.p: Mr. W. Redmond (N, Clare, East) in opposing the grant of £50,000 to Lord Cromer, said that he was not actuated by any personal motive or fooling against Lord Cromer. The reward of Lord Cromer should be derived from Egyptian sources and not from the taxpayers of this country. Was Lord Cromer to receive £50,000 because instead of carrying out the policy of evacuation, according to his orders, in Egypt, he had made that country into a British province? Lord Cromer was to be rewarded for doing that which could be characterised only as false and fraudulent in the face of the civilised world.(Opposition cries of "Shame" and general cries of "Withdraw.") Apart from public works and from the regulation of the finances of Egypt, Iord Cromer's work in that country had been singularly unsuccessful and unfortunate. eCries of dissent). The position in Egypt was the same as in Ireland. Every position of powor and emolument was held by Englishmen, while the Egyptians were hewers of wood and drawers of water in their own country. As to education, the Egyptians believed that the policy had been to keep the masses in a state of ignorance-(loud Ministerial cries of "No, no")-so as to render their political advancement an impossibility. (Renewed cries of "No, no.") This was one of the occasions on which it was difficult for him to ascertain what was the real difference between Liberals and Unionists. (Laughter.) He denied that the Department of Justice in Egypt had been put on a satisfactory basis. He objected to a subscription being got up for a man whose administration would be regarded as a blot upon the Empire. (Cries of "Oh, oh.")
Mr. Beaumont (L )-What rot !

Mr. William Redmond did not think that that was an expression which should come from an English gentleman, but one was not surprised when one recollected that the hon. member was a relative of Lord Clanricarde. (Loud Nationalist cheers.) .
Mr. Beaumont rose amidst, a storm of Nationalist cheers.
The Chairman said the hon. member wns not entitled to make such remarks. Did he rise to a point of order ? (Cheers.)
Mr. Beaumont said he did. He was quite willing to withdraw his remark. (Cheers). It was made in regard to the state of affairs in Egypt, and not in regard to what the hon. member said. (Cheers.)-

Mr. W. Redmond said it did not matter what was meant It was aimed at any system of Home Rule and self-government. It wns notorious that the efforts of Iord Egypt-(loud laughter) - he meant Lord Cromer - were against the freedom of the Egyptian people. (Cheers and laughter.)

Mr. Kettle (N, East Tyrone) said if it was true that Lord Cromer was a poor man it was to his credit, but that was no reason for taking £50,000 out of the pockets of people who were infinitely poorer. (Nationalist cheers.)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head:
THE BERBERINE NUISANCE
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Sir-There is a lot of talk of disaffection amongst the natives in Egypt, but this imaginary state of affairs is hardly due to the real Egyptian who is quite a peacable sort of person. I will not say that it is due to the Berberine, but really the attitude of these is unsupportable and becomes worse daily ; every house has its hand of Berberine loafers on benches or chairs outside, and their deliberations last well into the night and are exasperating to householders. There can be no reasonable objection to domestics discussing their affairs when their work is over, and incidentally their employers shortcomings, but that they should encumber the pavement and disturb the rest of those residing in the vicinity is insupportable. 1 have seen in your columns a well deserved justification of the efforts of the Cairo City Police in the face of huge difficulties but at the same time I think this is somewhat discounted by their cessation of the recent purging of the city of undesirables and unemployed of the black persuasion. In writing this I have strong hopes that the police will make an effort and resume their crusade against the Berberine pest, from which we all suffer, and. carry it through to the bitter end, as the matter is sufficiently serious and the discharged servants, saices, and even men in employment are disgrace fully insolent. , Yours faithfully

div.head: STOCK-JOBBER'S SUICIDE
div.p: About half past eleven yesterday morning two reports of a revolver were heard from the Belle Vue Café, near the Ramleh station, and those who rushed to the scene found a young Greek lying dead on the steps of the cafe. The man, who proved, to be a jobber on the Bonne, by name Dimitri Conatiridis, had shot himself in the cheat and the mouth.

div.head:
LORD CROMER
INTERESTING CHARACTER SKETCH
div.p: The following interesting character sketch of Lord Cromer appears in the "Daily Chronicle" of the 30th ult. from the pen of "Anglo- Egyptian" :-

It was Sunday sfternoon at the "Zoo" in Cairo. A little family party-father, mother, nurse and child - came strolling along. There was no state-no escort, no footman, no Consular "Cavasses" sparkling in gold and white, such as run, with their significant slaves, in front of the meanest foreign Consul in the streets of Cairo. It was just a little middle class party out for their weekly holiday- enjoying the sunshine, gazing at the strange animals-immensely concerned and interested in the baby-"Monsieur, Madame et Bébé"- the same group that you see wandering happily on Sundays under the plane trees in the Champs Elysées, or under the limes in any little German town. The man was grey-haired, but still keen-eyed, strongly built and bronzed of face. He seemed more anxious about the baby than either the mother or the nurse.
PHARAOH OR SLAVE ?

That was my first sight of Lord Cromer- three years ago ; and it gave me the key to his power over Egypt. Most Anglo-Indians believe that you must govern Orientals by display, and make themselves immensely ridiculous in the process. "The East bows low in deep disdain"-but it is not in the least impressed. All our Durbars leave them untouched. A white man in a frock coat, crowned with roses, is scarcely less absurd to them than to us. They can beat us so easily at that game. Lord Cromer's was quite another form of triumph. It was a victory of simplicity. The gewgaws of power-the balls and banquets, the palaces and attendants - were left to the Khedive and the Foreign Consuls. Lord Cromer kept the reality. But it was a terrrible life, and there is no wonder that he finds himself now, at sixty- five, condemned to an idleness which is the price of years of over-strain. At the end of his time Lord Cromer had concentrated in his hands almost every thread of the Government over 10,000,000 of human beings. Warned by a terrible illness, he had entirely given up all social life, which was charmingly looked after by his beautiful wife. "Early to bed and early to rise" was his iron law. Every morning he would see all his "Advisers"-the real Ministry of Englishmen, who control the shadowy Egyptian Cabinet. Everything of importance came up to him. He missed nothing-mastered everything. Then, in the afternoon, a drive, and again, at six, another set of audiences, a plain dinuer, and bed at nine. It was the life of a galley-slave. But be loved it with the passion of a true ruler. Nothing but a complete breakdown would have ever torn him from it. Think of his Egyptian record. Indian Viceroys rale for five years, and then, if they are wise, give way to others. Tropical Governors rarely remain beyond six, and even then come home with broken constitutions. Egypt, lived in the greater part ot the year, is almost as trying as India. But Cromer stayed it out for twenty- four years on his second stay. Before that he had been seven years in India, and one before in Egypt. Thirty-two continuous years of Oriental rule ! It is the biggest English record in that line. Egypt gradually became his only love. Others came and went. He stayed on. He refused the Viceroyality of India. He rejected the Foreign Ministry of the British Empire. With that Teutonic thoroughness which all the Barings have, he stuck to his one job, and preferred rather to do that thoroughly than to tinker at twenty others. He made his mistakes, like other men ; but, after all, what an Egypt he found, and what an Egypt he left! "READ MY REPORTS." The next time I saw Lord Cromer after that glimpse in the Cairo garden was in the British Consulate. There he lived and had his being. Characteristically of his rule, the house he inhabited was away from the centre of Cairo-a big Victorian building with a front garden and drive like a suburban villa-a house far less pretentious than that of many an Egyptian pasha. But though.it was remote, every Cairo driver-every fezzed "cabby" on those pretty little two horsed victorias that make life in Cairo so pleasant and elegant for the English visitor-know his way directly. "The Lord's ?" he asked with a swarthy grin- most of the drivers are Nubians-and with a proud crack of the whip you were bowled off at a reckless and dangerous pace. It was a high-ceilinged, sombre room I was ushered into, and the man I had seen at the Zoo was sitting at a table writing. After a few words of greeting he sat back from his papers and scanned me with a pair of very formidable eyes. "Have you read my reports?" I had to confess that I had not. Lord Cromer instantly rang a bell, and a clerk appeared. "Bring my reports," he said. The clerk disappeared, and came hack in a few minutes staggering under the burden. "Read those and come back again." I staggered away, read them, and came back. It was the beginning of a friendship. It was also the first step -to any real knowledge of Egypt. He has always been very proud of his reports, and quite rightly. No one should criticise Lord Cromer's rule in Egypt without

THE ENGLISH WAY. It was a wonder how he ever found time to write them. Knowing what it is to produce a book, I asked him once how he did it. "It is quite simple," he said, "I write them on my trips up the Nile." Every year in February or March he would leave Cairo and embark on a steamer up to the First, and sometimes the Second Cataract. Sitting on deck all day, he would write his Annual Report. It was the only place where he could be safe from intruders.

Lord Cromer went to Egypt a poor man and came away a poor man. Other Barings have heaped up or thrown away great wealth. Lord Cromer has made a nation fabulously wealthy, but he has reaped no profit himself beyond the salary he has spent at Cairo. The land values of Egypt have gone up 150 per cent., but it has been the iron role of the Egyptian Civil Service that no man among them should profit by one penny from that, Rather they have lost by the rise in the price living.

He is the last to ask any credit for that. Rightly, he regards it as the proper English rule—the rule for all Englishmen in such positions. Personally, he wishes, I feel sure, for no reward now. The "wreath of wild olive" would be the best prize for such services. But cash and public dinners are our English way; and that way must be followed.

Jet Liberals think seriously before they throw serious blame on such a rule. There are spots in the sun; and Lord Cromer at the end was a tired man. But on the whole, his record is the finest example of Liberal principles applied to empire. To discredit Lord Cromer is to encourage a ruler of a very different type.

div.head: FIRE IN CAIRO.
div.p: A fire broke out on Sunday night in the Egyptian Cavalry stables in a masonry building containing straw bedding. The call reached the Cairo Fire station at 10 p.m. and a steamer from Waili station was immediately on the spot followed by a steamer from Cairo. When the brigade arrived the fire had obtained a complete hold on the building and its highly inflammable contents, and Captain Jones, who was in charge, directed his efforts towards the isolation of the conflagration and the prevention of its spread to an adjoining cold store which happily escaped damage. | The water pressure was, poor but thanks to

the timely and devoted efforts of the Tanzim Department, who supplied water carts, a fair pressure was maintained and although some 250 tons of forage were alight the fire was restrained and mastered, but only after immense efforts.

The damage is estimated at £1,000 and at the time of writing a steamer is still playing on the smouldering debris which in the lower layers is still at white heat owing to the nature of the fuel which provoked the outbreak. The Egyptian troops are removing the debris as it cools but considerable labour is still entailed.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent suggests that at the present time, when so many people are short of money, it would be an opportune moment for those dividend paying Banks and Trading Companies that distribute their profits annually, to declare an interim payment now. By so doing he considers that the present situation would be ameliorated, and many shareholders, who are now being forced to sell to pay their way, would be in a position to hold their shares and gradually adjust their liabilities.

div.head: THE VANITY OF RAMESES II.
div.p: In a lecture at King's College last week, on the excavations of the Egypt Exploration Fund at Beir el Bahari, Professor Naville said one of the great annoyances of Egyptian explorers was to find the name of Rameses II. on many of the antiquities, some of which must have existed a thousand years before he was born. He apparently had always busied himself by having his name put on everything he possibly could, when it had no right and no business there.

In an interview appeaing in the "Evening News" Mr. Naville said that "Ramses II. did not deserve to be called the Great." The more we discover about him, the more we realise what a pious fraud he was. "His vanity was colossal, and he was not content with the fulsome praise of his own people. Being a man of broad ideas, he arranged that posterity as well should share his own opinion of his greatness.
"To this end he conceived the happy notion of causing his name to be inscribed on every temple, statue, and monument that he imagined would stand the test of time.
LEAVING HIS MARK.
"His plan succeeded only too well. For many years, in consequence of it, explorers have united in deciding that he must have been a great king.
"He wished to dazzle posterity, and he did so. But now we are beginning to find him out. Some of the antiquities on which his name appears must have existed quite 1,000 years before he was born.
"Occasionally he even went to the length of erasing the name formerly borne by a statue and substituting his own. He was never particular whose name it was that he erased.
"Frequently it was that of one of his predecessors. One wonders what the Egyptian 'man in the street' thought of it all

div.head:
HAFEZ AWAD INTERVIEWED.
THE MODERATE'S POLICY.
div.p: In an interview with a representative of the "Daily Chronicle," Hafez Bey Awad, rietor and editor of "Al Minbar" said : -

"Those who would correctly appreciate the political situation in Egypt must understand that there are several currents operating. There is the extreme section which clamours for complete autonomy. This section, if I may so put it, would like to run before it can walk. Their policy is to demand immediate evacuation, so that the Egyptian people may assume entire control of the affairs of the country. Then at the other extreme, there is the policy advocated by the Occupation Press and party, which desires that the present régime may continue indefinitely. These latter are not Egyptians, but Syrians, who have no right to speak for Egypt."

"I," said M. Awad langhingly, "am an unfortunate Moderate, and the party I represent does not agree with either of the extremist sections. At the same time I have no hesitation in saying that the Moderates are not only numerically the strongest party in Egypt, but they represent the substantial and responsible element in the population.

TO WORK WITH THE BRITISH. "What, you ask, is our poley? We say that the Egyptian people should work in harmony with the British authorities, and in such a way as to develop the institutions that were established by Lord Dufferin in 1882-83. We are not advocating anything violent or revolutionary. We desire for the present the development of the embryo constitution which was inaŭgurated, or, I might say, invented, by Lord Dufferin. At the present time, as everyone knows who has studied Egyptian politics, the institutions which have a semblance of a representative character are without legislative power. We Nationalists would like such powers conferred upon these institutions. We do not, of course, ask for full Parliamentary government at once, such as you have in England - that would be going too far-but it is our ultimate object. Our great desire is to work hand-in-hand with the English if the English will work hand-in-hand with us in developing our present institutions, For instance, one desirable reform for which we are asking would be direct election by the people to the Legislative Council and the General Assembly. At present the members of these two bodies are elected by the provincial councils."

Lord Cromer's resignation and Sir Eldon Gorst's appointment having been mentioned, the question naturally suggested itself, Do the Nationalists anticipate any concessions in the direction of their wishes ?

"We do not know," said M. Awad. "Sir Eldon Gorst is, I think, wisely saying nothing, We do not know what his intentions are, but we are hoping for some improvement, and our hopes are strengthened by the fact that there is a strong Liberal Government in power just now. There is, in fact, danger ahead unless something is done.

" What danger, you ask ? The danger that the Moderates, who represent the responsible people of the country, will, unless a considerable number of their demands are satisfied, throw in their lot with the extreme section That would be a calamity for England and for Egypt, which it would be impossible to exaggerate. We want to avoid that calamity, and it is by following our policy that it will be avoided. It must not be supposed that we do not appreciate all that has been done by England for Egypt on the side of its material prosperity ; our complaints are on the moral and political side."

NOT MORE LETHARGIC. It has been suggested by those who take an interest in Egypt's future that the Egyptian of to-day is more lethargic and indifferent, and less worthy of the full rights of citizenship than his countryman of the pre-Occupation period. This, M. Awad would not admit.

"There is undoubtedly," he said, "a reawakening of the national conscience, and it takes the form of a widespread feeling that the people should have a larger share in the government of their country than they at present possess. What better answer than that can you have to the aspersions? But the position is very unsatisfactory. Our just and reasonable claims have been too long denied, and this feeling that I speak of is what is meant when the newspapers talk about 'political unrest.' The feeling will go on increasing, and, as I say, may drive moderate men to the extremist side if nothing is done."
M. Awad had something to say about the educational system of the country.

"It is a superficial one," he said, "and does not bring out the young men who would be able to take high positions of responsibility, Instead of England, as she professed when she came to the country, preparing the people to govern themselves, she is, on the contrary, retarding the process. Knowledge, for instance, is imparted in two languages, English and French, and it is obvious that a student's mastery of a subject cannot be so thorough if he is taught in an alien tongue."
Asked in conclusion, what the success of the Nationalist movement would mean to the country, M. Awad spoke out strongly.

"It means," he said, "that you will have a people thoroughly loyal and thoroughly grateful to the British Government: instead of being covertly, if not openly, hostile. We Nationalists-and, by the way, I may say that we have not secret societies for the furtherance of our views --hold that the interests of England and

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Princess Sabba Hanem, wife of Mohemed Boy Ibrahim, arrived in London some days ago, and will spend the summer season with her mother and sister in England:
• Moheb Pasha, Governor of the Suez Canal, will leave Genoa on the 12th inst. for Port Said on board the N.D.L boat.
De Martino Pasha, Director-General of the Daïra Khassa, has embarked for Europe.
M. Probitzer, vice-consul of Austria-Hungary in Alexandria, left for Europe on Saturday.
Sir Reginald Oakes left yesterday for Europe, via Port Said.
Among the passengers who arrived yesterday morning from Europe, on board the Austrian Lloyd S.S. "Bohemia", were Saba Paslm, and Luzzatto Pasha, director of the Bank of Egypt.

Lieut. W. J. W. Steward, Inspecting Officer of the Galway Coastguard Division, who retired on the 11th inst. with the rank of commander, would have completed thirty years' service had he remained on four days longer. Commander Steward, who had held the rank of lieutenant since December, 1886, was midshipman of the "Monarch" at the bombardment of Alexandria and during the Egyptian War, 1882 (medal with clasp and bronze star). He had been at Galway since November, 1902.

The death is reported of Major St. George John Rathborne, retired list, late of the Royal Berkshire Regiment, aged 60. He joined the Army Dec. 2, 1865 became Captain Feb. 12, 1882 ; and Major Jan. 16, 1889, retiring in that rank on retired pay. As a subaltern of the 6th Regiment he served in the Afghan War, 1879-80, as transport officer with the Kurrum Valley Field Force (medal). He served with the 1st Batn. Royal Berkshire Regiment throughout the Egyptian War, 1882, and was present at the surrender of Kafr Dowar (medal and Khedive's star); served throughout the campaign in the Eastern Soudan in 1885, and was present at the engagement at Hasheen and Tofrek (mentioned in despatches) and the subsequent advance to and burning of Tumai, (two clasps); served with the Egyptian Frontier Force in 1885-86, and was present with the mounted infantry in the engagement of Giniss.

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: A.C.C. v. COLDSTREAM GUARDS.

The match played on Saturday on the Alexandria Cricket Ground between the A.C.C. and a team of the Coldstream Guards resulted in a very easy winner for the former. Winning the toss and taking first innings Alexandria immediately settled down to compile a good score and after Hay, who opened the innings with Carver, had been dismissed for 4 by a somewhat doubtful 1.b.w. Carver and Marsden made merry with the ball, which found the boundary time after time. Marsden played exceptionally well and placed his balls very neatly, and some good hard hitting was seen from Carver, who was obviously in form, though perhaps rather rash at times. Mainprice was most unlockily out l.b.w. to the first ball he received, but Scott Dalgleish further punished the Coldstream's bowlers to the tune of 51, and with five wickets down the Alexandria team declared the innings closed for 259. The Coldstreams fared almost worse with the bat than they did when in the field, and their only player who could stand up to the bowling of Carver and Prosser was Pte. Revell, who compiled more than half the total score by good all round play. Five of the players were missed for a duck, and the only man to reach double figures, besides Revell, was Mr. Bingham. Carver took five wickets for 21 and Prosser four for 18, Appended are the scores :-

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: La marché a ouvert faible ot eq bnisio et l'impreeflion a été plntAt défavorable pendant presque toute la séanoe. Mais, vers la fin; il s'est produit une amélioration, en particulier sur les valeurs dirigeantes, et en définitive l'ensemble de la cote a'fini en hausse. La note dominante a été, côinme ou le pense bien, l'indécision, on l'absence d'affaires sur le mar- ché de Londres qui chôme depuis samedi. On attend évidemment ponr se lancer ici de voir la direction que prendront les places diri- geantes. Les affaires ont été en général clairse- mées èt c'est plutôt à un retour de la demnnde qu'on doit la petite reprise de la clôture qu'à des transactions effectives. Ce sont les valeurs dirigeantes qui ont été le mieux tenues. La National Bank, d'abord délaissée et en réaction, a été l'objet en clôture d'une demande provenant du Caire. Il n'y a d'ailleurs parfeu d'échanges, les détenteurs ne se contentant pas des prix offerts. Le cour* s'est maintenu à 19 7/8. En Agricole dont le cours s'est consolidé à 8 1/16, il y a eu du mouvement et une demande assez active, sur- tout vers la fin. D'autre part, la Delta Light s'avance de 9 7/8 à 9 15/16 la Privilégiée et de 8 3/4 'à 9 1/4 la Dividende. L'Obligation Crédit Foncier est demandée à 304 l'ancienne et 262 la nouvelle. On a beauoonp remarqué des demandes en Tramways d'Alexandrie, Privilégiées et Divi- dendes, qui gagnent 2 francs aux cours res- pectifs de 139 1/2 et 292. C'est Bruxelles qui achète, paralt-il. A signaler également la reprise de la Iiand Bank de 7 à 7 3/16 vendeurs. Le motif de cette hausse n'est pas encore connu. En reprise encore la iUmleh de 4 1/2 à 4 5/8, la Béhéra de 20 à 20 1/4, la Delta Land de 1 11/16 h 1 8/4, ('Investment de 1/2 à 9.16, les Estâtes de 5/8'h 11/16, l'action Allotment de 2 1/8 à 2 1/4, la Levant de 9/16 à 19/32. la Sait and Soda fléchit, au contraire, de 17/6 à 17/3, la Cassa di Sconlo de 34 à 88, la Banque d'Athènes de 111 à 110 1/2, le ComJ>- toir de 2 11/16 k 2 5/8 l'action ancienne, de 2 5/8 42 9/16 la nouvelle et de 3 à 2 3/4 la part de fondateur, la Building de 2 7/16 à 2 5/16, la fondateur United de 2 1/4 à 2. Pour savoir si l'amélioration s'accentuera, il faut attendre la cote de Londres. Malgré les avis réitérés du Comité de I,'As- sociation des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie invitant les agente de change à régler au plutôt leurs transactions en Bourse & Banking, il parait que beauoonp ne se pressent pas de le faire. On commence même 4 douter de l'effi- cacité de' la mesure prise par l'association dans sou assemblée tenue récemment pour la liqui- dation de cette affaire. Un grand nombre d'in- téressés sont en effet résolus à ne pas régler leurs différences, les acheteurs entre autres qui n'ayant pas payé la .totalité "lu prix ont évi- demment intérêt h ne pas verser encore de l'argent ooutra un papier de valeur problé- matique. Ainsi, non seulement le comité ren- contre des adversaires résolus dans certains agente de change et dans tous les cliente l'ésés par sa décision, mais encore'une foule d'inté- ressés lui opposent une résistance passive contra laquolle viendront peut-être se briser ses derniers efforts.
CINEMATOGRAPHE UBANORA

Malgré la chaleur "pii nous accable, en ce moment, malgré les départs et malgré aussi la crise, la Grande Salle de I'Urbquora était pleine dimanche d'un public'toujours content de son Cinéma préféré. Les programmes sans cesse renouvelés sont'd'ailleurs composés pour satisfaire le public raffiné qui forme la clientèle deoet établissement modèle. Une mention spéciale pour les attractions qui paraissent ]iendant les entr'actes : Madame de Marnai/, chiyiteuse légère soulève les bravos nnaifhiie* d'une salle charmée d'en- tendre une aussi bq|lo et sympathique voix que tout le inonde retournera entendre. div.head: General Post Office
div.p: NOTICE.

The Postmaster General will receive up to the 5th September next at 10 a.m. tenders for the transport of mails at Alexandria. Tenders must be made out on stamped paper of 30 milliemes and must be enclosed in double envelope, addressed to the Postmaster General, Alexandria, the inner envelope bearing the indication "Tender for transport of Mails at Alexandria." The terms of the conract may be examined at the Secretary's Office, General Post Office, any time between the hours of 8 a.m. and 1 p.m. Sundays excepted. The Postmaster General does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any tender. Alexandria, August 5th 1907.

div.head:
MAVANEH VILLAGE DESTROYED
BARBAROUS CONDUCT OF TROOPS

div.p: Turkish troops with artillery entered Persia near Unimiah and destroyed the village of Mavaneh. They killed 18 men and 60 women or I'hihlren, mostly Christians and seized the neighbouring Persian camp. Another report sâys that 6,000 Persian cavalry have joined the Turks. ' ( Rutter)

The judgment given in the case of the Standard Oil Co. has caused a sensation throughout the country owing to the stupen- dous fine and the severe remarks of the judge, who likened the officials to couterieiters anl thieves and held out the prospects of indictments for conspiracy. Mr. Rockfeller was golfing when he heard the judgment but was quite unconcerned. The appeal will entail plentiful delays. {Reuter)

div.head:
GREECE AND TURKEY
THE BULGARIAN FRONTIER

div.p: Greece replying to the Turkish representa- tions declares that she is doing her utmost to prevent bands crossing the frontier, hut their presence is the outcome of Bulgarian misdeeds. She hopes tliat a remonstrance will also be addressed to Sofia. (Refiler)

div.head:
TSAR AND EMPEROR
PRECAUTIONS FOR SAFETY

div.p: The Tsar and the Emperor William attended a banquet on board the flagship "Deutsch- land." The Tsar presented Prince von Buelow with his portrait set in brillants. The most elaborate precautions have been taken for the safety of the Tsar who does not land. Nuiner nus torpedo boats surround the Imperial Yacht. ( Reuter)

. The meeting at Swi nom undo is attracting atteption. Germany is altogether likely to promote the interest of |"ace, especially in view of King Edwards coming interviews with the Emperors William and Francis Joseph. (Reuter)

div.head:
NIGERIAN RAILWAY SCHEME
COTTON GROWING DEVELOPMENT

It was estimated that the cost won Id be £1,230,000 One object of the railway was the developing 'of cotton growing. {Reuter.)

The Angers train, which was full of holiday makers, was derailed approaching the bridge and dashed through the parapet The engine, a luggage van, and a third class carriage fell into the river. The oocupante of the carriage wero drowned like rets in a trap. The coup- lings snapped and thus saved the remainder of the train. * {Reuter) ANOIKRS, August 5. div.head:

APPEAL FOR PROTECTION

div.p: The grain and flour merchants have presented a memorial to the Viceroy asking for protec tion for the carters and stating that lawless bands control the streets. A dozen strikers have received sentences varying from one to six months' imprisonment in connection with Saturday's disturbNifces. (Reuter)

div.head: HORTICULTURE IN EGYPT.
div.p: Horticulture haa been practiaed in Egypt for eome thousand* of yean, say* T. W. B in the "Gardener*' Chronicle" for July SO, hut no remain* of thene ancient garden* exist, and all the gardens of any note now existing in that country are the work ôf Europeans. Mohammed Aly Pasha and his son Ibrahim, in the first half of the nineteenth oentury, brought gardeners from England and France to lay out the gardens on the Isle of Roda at Cairo, and these became famous both for their beauty and for the collection of trees. Later, Ismail Pasha, Khedive of Egypt, em- ployed European gardeners and spent large sums of money in constructing extensive parks around his palaces at Giza and Gesireh. The public gardens of the Esbakieh, and most of the trees now growing in the street* and suburban roads of Cairo, were also planted under this ruler's direction. Rich Europeans and natives followed his example, so that many of the best Egyptian gardens of to-day date from the reign of Ismail Pasha. Since the time of occupation of the country by the British, the Government has been unable to attend to any matters other than those which are capable of providing revenue, and this may be also said of many private persons frho before had taken an interest in horticulture, so that, speaking generally, gardens in Egypt have during the last twenty-six yean been greatly neglected. During the recent boom in land speculation, numbers of estates were sold and out for building purposes. Of the beautifu gardens on the Isle of Roda little remains excepting a few trees, which, by chanoe, were not in the way of the roadmakers and builders, whilst at Giza and Getiroh the only remnants are the Zoological and Palace Hotel gardens. One, however, still finds beautiful but solitary specimens of exotic trees which tell their osm tale of the past At the present time interest in horticulture is again growing, and almost all the European resident* living outside the towns have their own gardens. Native gardeners are employed chiefly, although a few of the wealthier proprietors have brought met! from Europe. At Alexandria there is a thriving horticultural society, which is subsidised by the Government, and this association numbers amongst its members the best horticulturist* and botanist* in Egypt Mr. David Fish, late of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Edinburgh, is the secretary. An experimental station has been established ; seeds are being distributed, and exhibitions, which would do credit to any society in England, are held twice each year. The Khédivial Horticultural Society at Cairo is now being reorganised under /the name of la Société d'Horticulture Commerciale. Commercial horticulture in Egypt lias un- doubtedly a great future before it. A con- siderable and profitable trade is done in cut flowers, but it is mostly in the hands of small growers who give little or no attention to improving the quality of the produce which they offer for sale. Roses, which may bo said to grow like weeds, aro by far the commonest market flowers. Good blooms sold at Cairo last Christmas for a -shilling each. Violets and Chrysanternums are also largely grown for supplying, cut flowers, but Crysantbmmim flowers seldom compare favourably with those ono sees in the florists' sliope of Europe and America. o . Owing to the increasing number of people who spend the winter months in Egypt, the florists' business must in time become an important industry. The nursery trade is also capable of great development, and at present a demand exists for ornamental trees and shrubs, as woll as for treesfortheproductionof firewood, telegraph poles, etc. With few exceptions the nurserymen content themselves with the pro- pagation of those kinds which are already common in the country, and even for these the demand is greater than the supply, but there are hundreds of beautiful and useful plants which only need introducing to become popular. The .subjects now grown aro natives of varied climes ; trees from tho Northern States of America may be seen growing aide by side with others from Brazil and India. Many species of Palms will grow in the open air in Egypt,and plans are in preparation for the propagation, on a large soale, of these and other foliage plants for export to European markets. Plants grown in the ojien air are much hardier thjm those grown in hothouse*, and there appears little doubt of the snooess of the enterprise, especially lyi the cost will be small. Another branch of commercial horticulture in which great developments may be expected in the near future is the cultivation of fruit and vege- tables for export. Hitherto ootton and other purely agricultural crops have oocupied the attention of cultivators, to tlio exclusion of what have been regartled as garden crops. As the production of cotton is increasing in other countries, people in Egypt are asking themselves whether they are wiso in relying so fully on this crop. Many growers havo probably been deterred from fruit ' growing by knowing that they must wait three, four, or six years before receiving any returns from the trees, but they ignore the fact that vege- table crops may be grown between tl|o trees al- most up to the time they begin to fruit. The profits derived from the cultivation of vegetables and fruit* have in soveral cases far exceeded those derived from agricultural crops.

div.head: FINANCES OF THE ARMY
div.p: LACK OF FORESIGHT

The Second Report from tiie committee of Publio Accounts was issued last week. The Committee note* that the actual gross expenditure on the Army Votes during the year 1905-6 amounted to £32,043,809 11a 6d., being £1,396,9Î5 8a 64 less then the estimate. On the other hand the actual receipt* in aid of grants exoeeded the eetimated receipts by £799 9a 4d. The total rplus on Army Aooonnta was therefore £1,834,186 17a lOd. The surplus, which would have been larger by £945,000, but for the additional expenditure sanctioned by the Trea- sury on the re-armament of the Artillery, says the committee, is nearly twice as large as any that has occurred in Army Votes for the last twenty years, and is considerably in excess of the surplus on the combined votes of the Navy and Civil Servioes and Revenue Departments in the year under review, where an expenditure of £89,000,000 was involved. Prom the corres- pondence it must be further observed that the actual surplus on March 31,1906, was almost double the amount (£691,000) anticipated by the War Office in their forecast submitted to the Treasury as late as March 22, 1906. The point is not only one of initial estimate but of the large discrepancy between the War Office forecast (£691,000) of March 22, 1906, and the actual result (£1,384,136) of nine days later. So far as that discrepancy is con earned, the committee had no option but to accept the explanation furnished on behalf of the War Office. As regards the future, they are without assuranoe that a more satisfactory result may be expected. For, it has been explained to them that the military direotora (who now frame Estimates and control the progress of expenditure) "are transient officers who come to their post with very expensive notions, and only get to know their work thoroughly by tho time they have got to go and that as was admitted by the representative of the War Office, the financial shortcomings now under nntice may be repeated again, possibly periodically. It is not for your com mittee to indicate what administrative steps (if any) are necessary to ensure an efficient system. They confine tliemselves at the pres ent time to saying that the importance of accurately estimating expenditure and fore- casting liabilities cannot be too strongly insist- ed upon, and that they hope that the responsible Ministers of the day will take every means necessary to socure that end In regard to contracts, the committee states "The evidence before the War Stores Commis sion disclosed bribery in connection with various contracts for supplies. In accordance with the Bribery Clause inserted in all military contracts, a fine of 10 per cent, is recoverable in such cases. Messrs. Cowie and Houston were thus fined, and payments due to them withheld to make good the amount Your Committee note that in every established case of bribery the name of the firm is automatically removed from the list of Government contrac- tors. Messrs. May and Co. were also fined sums amounting to £3,309, but though the military authorities at tho time of cancellation of the contract hold funds due to the firm in excess of that amount, the Bribery Clause was over- looked, and the full amount paid over. As the advisability of instituting legal proceedings in this case is now under consideration, your Committee make no observation upon it The same applies in the cases of Messrs. Meyer, Mr. E. Stepney, and Mr. P.T. Richards.'' LOSSES'OP VARIOUS WORKS. A sum of more than £900, the committee notes, was spent, in addition to a previous outlay of £3,000, in building a shed Tor the construction of an elongated balloon The manufacture, however, proceeded so slowly that by tho time the shod was com- pleted other buildings had arisen in the vicinity which forbade the elongated bal- loon. its necessary access to the upper air. The factory was therefore removed from Aldershot to Swan Plateau at an estimated cost for removal and re erection of £10,000. The money spent on the shod was not all wasted, as tho building !>ecaino available for military workshop, but the committee consider that there was some look of fores- ight in this matter. In connection with expenditure under the Military Works Loan Acta the committee'* attention had been drawn by the Comptroller and Auditor-Gen- eral to the following instances of the lots of public money due to successive changes of policy: At East Bulford there had been a loss to the- publio of between £140,000 and £150,000 in erecting a Mounted Infan- try School, which was closed on the 1st of July, 1906, whilst at Tidworth nearly a million pounds had been expended in building barracks for eight Infantry battalions, though only four were needed. The surplus barracks were being altered at to honse a Cavalry regimant and certain other troops. Near Fermoy, a ram of £85,000 was expended in 1905-6 for the purchase of Moore Park (848 seres, with mansion and grounds) as a site for barracks and for training Mounted Infantry. The idea of a Mounted Infantry School in Ireland bas now been dropped, and the mansion and outbuildings are used for the purpose of providing accommodation for a field company of Royal Engineers. At Stoba, where the original idea was to make a great training ground for troops, but it had been given up, the War Office had spent only £66,000 out of the £795,000 which had been intended at a time when it was anticipated to have six Army Corps ; the land purchased being used mainly for Volunteer estops. The oouunittee add that they hope to be able to roc^k this, subject next year, when, on the ^Rtary Works Aota Aooonnta for 1906-7, tA^imp trailer and Auditor-General will be in a position more folly to set opt the total low of public money which, under the loan system now drawing to a dose, has resulted from ex- penditure on projects subsequently discarded as useless.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MERCHANT DIVORCE.
div.p: WIFE CONFESSON AFTER 19 YEARS.

In.the Divorce court last week, Mr. William Getty) cotton merchant, of Alexandria, peti- tioned for a divorce on the ground of the mis- conduct of his wife, Caroljfie Bertha. Mr. Barnard, K.C., in opening the case, said the parties were married on July 22,1885, and went to reside at Alexandria. In 1886, in consequence of some dispute, the wife's sister left the house, and almost directly the wife followed, declining to live with her husband. She came to England, writing her husband an affectionate letter. Despite all his effort*, Mr. Getty could not ascertain his wife's whereabouts until 1888. In that year Mr. Getty received information that hi* wife wa* ill, and he sent her a cheque through the sister, but the cheque was returned, Mrs. Getty refusing to accept aid. In 1899 Mr. Getty started proceedings for restitution of conjugal righto, which be ultimately abandon- ed, agreeing to a deed of separation in Novem- ber, 1900. On December 28, 1904, Mrs. Getty wrote to her husband - - "My dear William,-I am a Christian Scientist I became interested in science from the healing of Vera's husband, who was snppoeed to have an incurable disease. I believe that God iB divine in principle, light truth, and lova I want to possess the consciousness of Truth, and cannot do so while I am not truthfpl with you. "I was unfaithful to you nearly nineteen years ago. I regret bitterly the wrong I have done you.-" v "This statement sounds bald, but it is too ugly to dress up iu fine phrases. Yours vory sincerely, Carolino B. Getty." She also wrote to the trustees of her mar- riage settlement saying she desired the interest of the fund of about £1100 in future to be paid to her husband. Finding this could not be done, she wrote to her husband "Dear'Willie,-I have tried to hand over to you the settlement money, only to learn it was impossible. Then I tried to have the interest of it paid over to you, and that also is impossible I am told. Therefore, I write now to ask if you will let rae send it on to you every six months when it is paid to me. "Do not think I mean to and insult to injury. I feel the money is yours, and not mine nt alL" His Lordship granted a decree nisi.
